. That is simply not a good idea, but you could probably get around it via:
[ProtoMember(4)]
public SomeType TheOriginalProperty {get;set;}
then migrating to:
```
[ProtoMember(4)]
public SomeType TheOriginalProperty {...}
public bool ShouldSerializeTheOriginalProperty()
{
    return false;
}
[ProtoMember(12)]
public int TheNewProperty {...}
```
with one of the two properties being the "actual" code, and one of them
being a shim that has the code to translate between the two. This approach
will allow both old and new data to be read, but data will always be
written using the new layout.

. This is actually the correct application of reading an individual value; in
the protobuf wire format, streams can be directly appended. If a field is
duplicated, it is the last occurrence that wins (except for sub-items,
where they are merged). To do anything different would be to parse the data
incorrectly. To read lists, you should use the separate "items" based
method - apologies, I am on mobile and don't have the name to hand.

On 8 Oct 2014 11:05, "tbella" notifications@github.com wrote:

The BufferPool throws OutOfMemory exception when serializing large objects
on x86 platforms. In our case one of the fields is a byta array containing
64 MB data. Possible improvements:
- Remove buffering from ProtoWriter: dirently write to the stream,
  buffering should be performed by the underlying stream.
- Do not only cache default-sized buffers. The real gain would be in
  caching big buffers allocated on the Large Object Heap. They are
  responsible for memory fragmentation and also more expensive to re-allocate.
- Use weak references for cached buffers. They could be automatically
  collected in low-memory situations.
- Re-use cached buffers in ResizeAndFlushLeft method.

. So to be clear, then; what makes you think there is a problem? The 9 bytes in the binary you posted most recently says:
"field 11, string, length 7" (2 bytes)
    "field 3, string, length 5" (2 bytes)
        "SOLNA" (5 bytes)
If field 11 is a location with Coordinate = null, Accuracy = 0 and City = "SOLNA", then that is entirely reasonable. So: what makes you think there is an issue? What is the symptom? 
. From your comment here:

The first thing it reads, inside this nested message, is buffer position 202: 7. It uses the two lines above making tag=7 and therefore fieldNumber=0.

what you are describing here is a bug in protostuff; a tag with value 90 indicates a length-prefixed type (aka "string"). The correct thing to do next is to read a varint, which indicates the length of the content - in this case, 7 bytes. The content starts after the 7. If protostuff isn't reading the varint that denotes the length: then it is doing it wrong. You can refer to the "Strings" and "Embedded Messages" sections of the encoding spec for more information.

. Ah, this is probably the annoying "implicit defaults" - an early design choice that is much regretted. Try adding:
[DefaultValue(true)]
To the property. That should hopefully fit it.
. This is simply a poor design choice that happened many many years ago in v1 of protobuf-net. What I should have done is only use explicit default values. How the code was implemented - and remains the default, for compatibility - is that it assumes "zero" as the default, unless told otherwise (or unless some kind of conditional serialization is in play, for example Nullable-of-T, ShouldSerialize, or Specified). There is actually an option to disable this if you create your own RuntimeTypeModel instance rather than using .Default - something like ".UseImplicitZeroDefaults".
The [DefaultValue(true)] in this case simply gives the library more clue as to what is an actual value vs a default.
. the fundsmental thing here is that the .proto schema proessing needs a
singnificant overhaul (read: rewrite) in order to be viable in the
xplat/core-clr world. This would be a natural thing to fold into that, but
in some ways I'm reluctant to stir too hard at the old protoc/xslt code.
the good-ish news is that it is all protocol compatible, but I acknowledge
that it is inconvenient to do so. Needs work, and I have a chunk of time
earmarked for protobuf-net love this quarter.

. Actually, there is something you can do here if and only if the additional data is a direct child of the original root object. For example: if the original is:

Foo {
    a = 1;
    b = 2;
    repeated c = 3;
}
The protobuf format is both:
- appendable (append===merge)
- not required to be in order
This means that you can actually drop the "b" part (for example) onto the wire separately from the rest, simply by appending it correctly. To append with the right headers, the easiest thing to do is to create a dummy object with just the b:
FooBOnly {
    b = 2;
}
Now you can:
- serialize a Foo that doesn't include a "b"
- serialize a FooBOnly with a "b"
When the receiver seaerializes as Foo, it will merge both parts automatically.
Any use?

. I don't think it is a good idea to leak the actual ioBuffer, because that is leased from the BufferPool -  basically:
- the contents might have been changed completely by another caller by the time the recpient sees it
- it would allow the recipient to screw up someone else's ioBuffer

I'd be fine with adding context about the position, length, etc... but the ioBuffer: probably not a good idea
. I would also question the usefulness; it isn't like xml and json - most people won't have a clue how to interpret the data.
. the only way to safely do that would be to grab the data from the ioBuffer before adding it to the exception, so the only thing you're adding is isolated; however, protobuf is a binary format, and in the general case we should not expect it to be likely to contain text
. ioBuffer can be pretty huge, though - I would advise only copying (say) a max of 100 bytes either side of where it exploded (would need some min/max checks, etc); additionally, note that you should only look at most at the known available bytes - anything past that point is potentially garbage and unrelated to the current problem: it would be unnecessarily confusing to report that as though it were part of the problem, when it isn't.
Finally, in terms of allocation and large blocks, this isn't ideal - it kinda feels like this should be opt-in (although it is fine if the message says "enable ShowBufferContentsInExceptions to view the data at the time of the error", or something like that)

all. Protobuf-net adds limited inheritance support, but things like
multiple inheritance is complex; to do that properly would require
considerable design, implementation and testing, for what is an edge
scenario - and arguably one better served by mapping to a simpler DTO model
that (as is the nature of DTOs) reflects the reality of the serialisation
paradigm.

This isn't on my planned list of things to do. If someone can absorb the
time to properly specify, proove (i.e. that it is unambiguous, etc),
design, implement, test, document and support it - I would consider a PR

. 1: yes
2: in terms of the protobuf specification, each sub-type is implemented as
an optional sub-message using that numeric identifier
3: this is not uncommon in serialisation; compare/contrast [XmlInclude];
the problem is that during deserialization the only thing you usually know
is the parent, hence it becomes necessary for the parent to know about the
derived types

. The false in Add(Type, bool) says "don't process anything yourself; I'm going to tell you what to do, explicitly". Hence, you need to tell it about the default value yourself in this case. In code:
var typeMeta = RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(Foo), false);
    typeMeta.AddField(1, "Bar").DefaultValue = 0;
(I only introduced typeMeta in this example because you probably want to add multiple fields)
Note: if you are using C# 6:
typeMeta.AddField(1, nameof(Foo.Bar)).DefaultValue = 0;

isn't actually "boxing", but... either way: sorted.

. Protobuf-net needs to know numbers for each field you want to serialize. There are ways to make this semi-automated, but the easiest way would be to explicitly mark them:
```
[DataMember(Order=1)]
public string ABC {get;set;}
[DataMember(Order=2)]
public int QWE {get;set;}
```
That should fix it.
. Well, in this scenario the first thing I'd note is that using implementation details (such as Microsoft.Crm.Sdk.Entity) in serialization layers is not a great idea - it creates a huge number of traps. Frankly, if serialization of an existing object model becomes non-trivial, the best approach is not "fight the serializer" but rather "create a simple DTO that fits the serializer perfectly"
As it happens, protobuf-net does have things like ImplicitFields that can help in some of these scenarios, but it only looks at the declaring type, not base-types - so it wouldn't pull from Entity. protobuf-net also has the ability to configure types manually, but that would require you adding code to your app-init. But to give an example broadly similar to yours:
```
using ProtoBuf;
using ProtoBuf.Meta;
using System;
using System.Runtime.Serialization;
class Program {
    static void Main() {
        RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(MyObj), false).Add("Foo", "Bar", "Name");
        var obj = new MyObj { Name = "abc", Foo = 123, Bar = "def" };
        var clone = Serializer.DeepClone(obj);
        Console.WriteLine(obj);
        Console.WriteLine(clone);
    }
}
[DataContract] public class MyObj : Entity {
    [DataMember] public string Name { get; set; }
    public override string ToString() => $"{Name}, {Foo}, {Bar}";
}
[DataContract] public class Entity {
    [DataMember] public int Foo { get; set; }
    [DataMember] public string Bar { get; set; }
}
```
Note here that the order of the members in Add defines their wire identity - so Foo is 1, Bar is 2, etc. Depending on your C# version, you may also wish to look at nameof rather than hard-coded strings:
RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(MyObj), false).Add(
            nameof(Entity.Foo), nameof(Entity.Bar), nameof(MyObj.Name));
Is any of that useful?
. Microsoft.Xrm.Sdk.AttributeCollection is basically a
Dictionary, which protobuf-net is going to hate. The
protobuf format is designed to serialize models with a well-known shape /
format - which "object" isn't. There is no good way to handle a
string-object map in protobuf; there are some bad ways, but that depends a
lot on what the actual values are in your scenario.
. The problem isn't the map - protobuf-net would happily support
Dictionary<string,Project>, to use the example from your links; it is the
"object". Protobuf wants to know what it is deserializing. So again: what
are the actual values?

That is expected. It knows that in the general case it doesn't know how to
work with "object", so it isn't happy to start trying, unless it has been
specifically configured to treat it as a string-string map. But
fundamentally, I would again simply suggest that anything based on this
much implementation details rather than data details isn't a good choice
for serialization. The preference here (IMO) would be to create a DTO
model specifically intended for serialization, that represents the data
you want to serialize, rather than the active object model you happen to be
using at the timel

. oddly, no not really. You see, there aren't any binary serialization format
changes between proto2 and proto3, so you can already do everything. The
DSL changes just make it more elegant in some cases if you're using .proto
schemas. Which has never been a hard requirement in protobuf-net. The
runtime in proto3 for protobuf-net aren't huge - the biggest things are the
addition of Duration / Timestamp support and cleaner Map handling, but:
they're done. I haven't started the attribs=>proto3 work; proto3 is
actually a subset of proto2, not a superset as you might imagine. The
challenge for me will be to see what I can live without :)

```
[TestFixture]
public class ReadOnlyPropertyBugTest
{
    [Test]
    public void StructIsRoundTripped()
    {
        CustomStruct value = new CustomStruct( "I'm a description ^_^", DateTime.UtcNow );
    using ( MemoryStream memory = new MemoryStream() )
    {
        Serializer.Serialize( memory, value );
        memory.Position = 0;
        CustomStruct deserialized = Serializer.Deserialize<CustomStruct>( memory );
        deserialized.Should().Be( value );
    }
}

[ProtoContract]
private struct CustomStruct : IEquatable<CustomStruct>
{
    public CustomStruct( string description, DateTime importantDate )
    {
        Description = description;

. K; I've fixed the library to stop it exploding, but the fundamental problem here is that a type (to protobuf-net) can either be a leaf or a list, not both; in being enumerable of itself, it tries to be both. The code isn't going to like the "list" style (it ... just doesn't parse), so it now reverts to "leaf". This will, however, mean that to get this to behave as you expect, you will need to still expose the downstream tree; this could be done by:

[ProtoMember(3)] // or whatever
protected List<TreeObject> _children =
. Note: to fix this using the existing library, you should be able to do:
[ProtoContract(IgnoreListHandling = true)]
class Problematic : IEnumerable
{
    [ProtoMember(3)] // or whatever
    protected List<TreeObject> _children =
here the IgnoreListHandling is checked before the code that is currently causing it to explode.
. The problem here is that it grarually becomes prohibitively and
disproportionately time consuming to support older runtimes. For context,
MS .NET 4.51 support ended over a year ago (
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2014/08/07/moving-to-the-net-framework-4-5-2/
).
This is especially challenging given the changes to the build process etc.
Which needs another overhaul for the csproj changes, but that's another
story.
The long and short, then, will be:

if I do the csproj changes (imminent) and the old versions "just work"
(meaning: fall into place without me going crazy), then great: I'll include
them
otherwise, if someone can figure out what the csproj and build changes
are to make it successfully target those versions without causing problems,
then a PR will be gratefully received and merged

Historically I have tried to consider back-level - heck, it even used to
compile on C#1.2 (.Net 1.1), and might still do so! But: there comes a time
when it isn't the best use of my time to try to do so.
I also have concerns that continuing to support these very very old
runtimes is me being an "enabler" when what I should actually be doing is
advocating for you to move to an up to date framework.

do), then: job done - enable that


If your code-gen tool creates "partial" classes, you can create a
second file with the same "partial" class and add your attributes
there. In place of [ProtoMember], there's a [ProtoPartialMember] that
can be applied at the class level (instead of the member level), simply by
telling each one the name of the member it applies to.
Finally, you can configure everything at runtime using RuntimeTypeModel.

. thanks. Usually I would expect the reader to be collectable about the same time, but; yeah, this should be fine. Thanks.. The  schema processing tools have not been updated to parse proto3. The
binary format, however, is unchanged - so as long as you understand how
proto3 translates to the object model, it is readily consumable. I'm open
to offers from anyone who wants to update the schema parsing tooling - they
are long overdue some love. But the primary API in protobuf-net has
always been code-first, which simply isn't impacted at all by proto3.

On 25 November 2016 at 09:26, Anton van Dijk notifications@github.com
wrote:

An issue could be that the stream is being read at the wrong position.
Besides that, it might not be done writing when you're calling the
deserialize.
Instead of:
var serverStream = new MemoryStream();
ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(serverStream, responseMsg);
Console.WriteLine($"responseMsg {responseMsg?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");
var response =ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize(serverStream);
Console.WriteLine($"response {response?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");
Try:
var serverStream = new MemoryStream();
ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(serverStream, responseMsg);
Console.WriteLine($"responseMsg {responseMsg?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");
serverStream.Flush();
serverStream.Position = 0;
var response =ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize(serverStream);
Console.WriteLine($"response {response?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");

process 2.0 data (the data format is unchanged in 2.0) - but only if you're
using correctly configured code-first implementations. It cannot currently
automatically generate classes to represent a 2.0 schema.

wrote:

I wrote a test that can exercise this issue:
    [TestMethod, TestCategory("RecruitmentEdge"), Owner("RecruitmentEdge@careerbuilder.com")]
    public void Verify_Protobuf_Serialization()
    {
        using (var writeStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream())
        {
            ISet<String> mySet = new HashSet<String>();
            mySet.Add("hello world");

            ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(writeStream, mySet);

            using (var readStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream(writeStream.ToArray()))
            {
                var myDeserializedSet = ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize<ISet<String>>(readStream);
                Assert.AreEqual(mySet.First(), myDeserializedSet.First());
                Assert.AreEqual("hello world", mySet.First());
            }
        }

        using (var writeStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream())
        {
            IDictionary<DayOfWeek, ISet<String>> myMap = new Dictionary<DayOfWeek, ISet<String>>();
            myMap.Add(DayOfWeek.Monday, new HashSet<string> { "hello world" });

            ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(writeStream, myMap);

            using (var readStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream(writeStream.ToArray()))
            {
                var myDeserializedMap = ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize<IDictionary<DayOfWeek, ISet<String>>>(readStream);
                Assert.AreEqual(myMap[DayOfWeek.Monday].First(), myDeserializedMap[DayOfWeek.Monday].First());
                Assert.AreEqual("hello world", myMap[DayOfWeek.Monday].First());
            }
        }
    }

Also, is it possible that you have the same repeated object in the tree
multiple times? (for example, a City object where 20 customers all have the
same City instance) - protobuf-net is a tree serializer by default, so that
data would be repeated. BF is a graph serializer that uses object tracking
- however protobuf-net also has this as an optional feature.

. This appears to be fixed - I think via a contributed PR at some point. Closing.. There is a pre-existing Serializer.NonGeneric.TryDeserializeWithLengthPrefix, but that takes an awkward TypeResolver; will look at the PR (and: sorry for delay, I've been.... distracted). Re "really big integers": that's actually part of the protobuf spec (https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/proto):
The smallest tag number you can specify is 1, and the largest is 229 - 1, or 536,870,911.

(unless the obsolete and undocumented "message-set" encoding is used, but protobuf-net doesn't support message-set encoding - it isn't even part of the formal specification, although I've reverse-engineered it and understand what it needs to look like)
However, I'm happy to check to see that appropriate and useful errors are being raised.  The exception thing (base class) - yup, sounds like a bug. Will target both in 2.31. you're absolutely right, of course; either it needs to work, or it needs to fail as early as possible with a meaningful message; I've shipped 2.3.0, so I'm starting the 2.3.1 work currently (this issue is tagged for 2.3.1).. appreciated, thanks. if the main issue here is UWP, that's on the roadmap as a future item. This is an interesting one; I need to think about how this should work. The non-trivial part of the issue is that enums in protobuf are only defined for 32-bit values. However, since 2.3.0 adds much improved enum pass-thru support (consistent with proto3 runtime behaviour), it might be that we can simply treat long enums as direct pass-thru. Needs consideration. Adding to 2.3.1. The previous comment is correct, but to be more specific: because you write
multiple times to the same stream without rewinding/clearing the contents,
you are essentially concatenating all the objects into a single stream -
so the overall length of data will be (number of objects)*(size of object).
As an aside, this also means it isn't a like for like performance test,
especially for deserialization!
Now, protobuf is designed such that append===merge. So from protobuf's
perspective, you have written a single object with many many key/value
pairs - most of which are duplicates. If you ever need to do what you are
doing here (writing multiple objects sequentially), the
SerializeWithLengthPrefix and DeserializeWithLengthPrefix methods will help
you - basically they allow you to tell the system how to identify
individual objects. However, in your case what you should probably do is
rewind and clear the stream between writes, so:
for(...) {
    ms.Position = 0;
    ms.Length = 0;
// not shown: serialize to ms here

}
// read the contents of the final write:
var arr = ms.ToArray();

. This isn't a scenario that the library targets or that I intend the library to target; my advice here would be: always initialize your lists. For example
[ProtoMember(1)]
public List<Foo> Items {get; } = new List<Foo>();

protobuf-net is fine with things like that. If you want lazier initialization, then you can do that with more nuanced getters, for example:
private List<Foo> _items;
[ProtoMember(1)]
public List<Foo> Items => items ?? (_items = new List<Foo>());

which again: protobuf-net is fine with.
When the 3.0.0 codegen code changes are a thing, it might be that this is something we can target there, but: ultimately I'm not sure this is protobuf-net's thing to do.
Note that root-level lists are initialized, but that's a very different scenario.. To quote from the homepage:
install
Nuget : Install-Package protobuf-net
The nuget link is https://www.nuget.org/packages/protobuf-net/, but as
mentioned - the most common way to install would be via the package manager
in Visual Studio.

. protogen has been completely rewritten for 2.3.0; this will be working in the 2.3.0 release.

Note, however, that it is now strongly recommended (by Google) to always have a zero value as the first item in an enum. This is a requirement for proto3 (you are using proto2 by default, since you don't have syntax = "proto3";). Fixed in 2.3.0; example output:
```
[global::ProtoBuf.ProtoContract()]
public partial class EnumFirstIsNonZero
{
    [global::ProtoBuf.ProtoMember(1, Name = @"optional")]
    [global::System.ComponentModel.DefaultValue(Foo.A)]
    public Foo Optional
    {
        get { return __pbn__Optional ?? Foo.A; }
        set { __pbn__Optional = value; }
    }
    public bool ShouldSerializeOptional() => __pbn__Optional != null;
    public void ResetOptional() => __pbn__Optional = null;
    private Foo? __pbn__Optional;
[global::ProtoBuf.ProtoMember(2, Name = @"required", IsRequired = true)]
public Foo Required { get; set; } = Foo.A;

}
```. At a complete guess: IL2CPP is doing "pruning" to reduce the final size,
removing things that it can't see evidence for usage. There's usually
attributes you can add, or other configuration options, to tell a pruning
tool to leave something alone. Apply that to your DTOs.

. All great extra context, thanks. Merged.. All good extra context, cheers. Merging as another interesting comparison / line in the sand - but in that outcome we'd just use Task<T> from the outset - both have the same allocation issue, and direct Task<T> is marginally faster. Odd that it is faster to wrap a ValueTask<T> into a Task<T> than to use await on the original ValueTask<T>!. If I get a chance later I'll try with float and double (without a reference wrapper) - see if there's a stack size limit where the suckage starts.. The protobuf format doesn't include field names, so the code needs some mechanism to know which members map to which field numbers in the data, and it needs to be reliable, i.e. you'll always get the same mapping - today, tomorrow, and two months from now.

one of the ways to do this is by annotating the object via attributes - this can be done via any of [ProtoMember], [DataMember] or [XmlElement] (in the last two cases, you will need to include the field number in the optional Order member). If you have code-generated entity models, there is also a [ProtoPartialMember] that can be added in a separate partial class file to allow you to attach numbers to members in the generated file without having to edit the generated file.
Another way you can do it is by asking the library to just assume that you're never going to change your type, and use the alphabetical order of the members.  You would do this via [ProtoContract(InferTagFromName = true)] - or to apply this as a more general default: RuntimeTypeModel.Default.InferTagFromNameDefault. However, this should not be done lightly - it makes your types very brittle - adding, removing or renaming members can (will) make the data unreliable.
Individual types can also be configured entirely manually using the RuntimeTypeModel / MetaType API in the library.
Would any of those options suffice? If you are more specific about what issue you are facing, I can advise further.. > Please suggest something
to repeat:

Would any of those options suffice? If you are more specific about what issue you are facing, I can advise further.

You haven't told me what problem you are facing or where you're stuck.. You haven't rewound the MemoryStream - if you are "old school" like me, think of VHS or audio cassettes: the MemoryStream is currently at the end, there is nothing to read. As it happens, 0 bytes is a perfectly valid length to protobuf. All you need is ms.Position = 0;.
Additional notes:

var dcat = Serializer.DeepClone(cat); would do all of this in one go
the generic Serializer.Serialize(ms, cat) and Serializer.Deserialize<Cat>(ms) API may be easier for you to use. because that isn't how you usually use streams - indeed, most streams
arent rewindable (TCP sockets, etc). MemoryStream is a very unusual case
usually people don't write and read to the same stream in this way.

. GetBuffer returns the oversized array that MemoryStream uses to avoid
allocating for every write. You should never use GetBuffer without also
checking .Length and limiting your access to exactly that many bytes.

Protobuf-net got the message entirely correct :)
Either use ToArray when storing to redis, or check .Length and use
ArraySegment(ms.GetBuffer(), 0, ms.Length) if your redis client
support that or similar.

. Well that's embarrassing. I suspect you're right! . Hi; for some reason all my usual github notifications got blown away, so I only noticed this because of @nathvi 's comment (I rebuilt all my notifications the other day). I will look this evening and see what's wrong.. I'm assuming that myIP is an IPEndPoint. For the purposes of testing this, I generated a random IP and am using:

var myIP = new IPEndPoint(IPAddress.Parse("220.5.105.207"), 6379);

This fails in the way you describe.
You can see the problem here if we look at the stacktrace:
Unhandled Exception: System.Net.Sockets.SocketException: The attempted operation is not supported for the type of object referenced
   at System.Net.IPAddress.get_ScopeId()
   at IPAddressSurrogate.op_Implicit(IPAddress value) in C:\Users\mgravell\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ConsoleApp12\ConsoleApp12\Program.cs:line 44
Notice that it is failing when accessing the ScopeId, and sure enough - if we forget about protobuf, and just look at myIP.ScopeId, that alone is enough to make it fail. So; let's assume we don't need that and just throw it away (remove ScopeId completely in the surrogate and operators).
This now (for me) fails with a complaint about no wire-value for InterNetwork. I think this is just because the surrogate feature was never intended to work with enums; if we remove all mention of AddressFamilySurrogate, the code now runs, but doesn't actually serialize anything - that's because IPAddressSurrogate has no members marked for serialization - but... on investigation, I don't think we even need IPAddressSurrogate - the only interesting property that we actually need to store is IPString - or the bytes equivalent. I'm going to stick with the string approach.
Next I notice that the conversion operators are failing because of the null initial values - conversion operators on reference types need to handle null (usually by passing it through).
And you don't seem to be storing the Port, which is essential.
At this point I took a step back, because I think you're making this way, way more complicated than necessary. I'm pretty sure that all you need is:
```
[ProtoContract]
public class IPEndPointSurrogate
{
[ProtoMember(1)]
public string Address { get; set; }

[ProtoMember(2)]
public int Port { get; set; }

public static implicit operator IPEndPointSurrogate(IPEndPoint value)
    => value == null ? null : new IPEndPointSurrogate { Address = value.Address.ToString(), Port = value.Port };

public static implicit operator IPEndPoint(IPEndPointSurrogate value)
    => value == null ? null : new IPEndPoint(IPAddress.Parse(value.Address), value.Port);

}
```
with example usage:
```
public static class P
{
    public static void Main()
    {
        RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(IPEndPoint), false)
            .SetSurrogate(typeof(IPEndPointSurrogate));
    var myIP = new IPEndPoint(IPAddress.Parse("220.5.105.207"), 6379);
    using (var ipStream = new MemoryStream())
    {
        Serializer.Serialize(ipStream, myIP);
        ipStream.Position = 0;
        var clone = (IPEndPoint)Serializer.Deserialize<IPEndPoint>(ipStream);
        Console.WriteLine(clone.ToString());

        // prove it worked:
        Console.WriteLine(ReferenceEquals(clone, myIP)); // false, different objects
        Console.WriteLine(Equals(clone, myIP)); // true, count as equivalent
    }
}

}
```

Re ClaimsPrincipal; I don't know enough about that type. What do you actually need to serialize to store and rehydrate one of those? I genuinely don't know. However, protobuf-net includes features that allow you to get the serializer to automatically use a  simple DTO (serializaiton) type in place of a complex POCO object as long as you provide a method to get between them. So if you can say "to work a ClaimsPrincipal I need to store a string, 3 integers and a boolean" - then I can tell you how to get it to do that.. K
Option 0:
My preferred option would be to serialize an object model that just doesn't have the complex non-serializable thing in it. Leave that entirely in the code that is downstream. That isn't always possible, so:
Option 1:
Retain your existing model, but have a shim property on your type; so while you might have:
public SomethingComplex ProblematicProperty {get;set;}

you could add:
[ProtoMember(12)]
private SomethingSimple ProblematicPropertySerialized {
    get { /* convert from ProblematicProperty */ }
    set { /* convert from value and assign into ProblematicProperty */ }
}

(and you write a SomethingSimple type that meets your needs and works with the serializer)
however, I acknowledge that this also isn't always possible. In that case, you can hack around it with...
Option 2
a surrogate - the key point here is the SetSurrogate method which expects there to be conversion operators between the two types (on the assumption that you're writing the surrogate type specifically for this purpose, so that's fine); you can see this in the runnable example below. The idea is the same, but instead of using a shim property, the library does that step for you.
And to answer your question: no, don't touch ISerializable
```
using ProtoBuf;
using ProtoBuf.Meta;
class Program
{
    static void Main()
    {
        var obj = new MyData { Id = 1, Foo = new ComplexNonSerializableClass() };
    RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(ComplexNonSerializableClass), false)
        .SetSurrogate(typeof(SimplerThingThatLooksSimilar));
    var clone = Serializer.DeepClone(obj);
}


[ProtoContract]
public class MyData
{
    [ProtoMember(1)]
    public int Id { get; set; }
    [ProtoMember(2)]
    public ComplexNonSerializableClass Foo {get;set;}
}

public class ComplexNonSerializableClass
{
     // ... real code here, obviously - although this probably isn't
     // your type in the first place - it is probably a BCL type
}

[ProtoContract]
public class SimplerThingThatLooksSimilar
{
    public static implicit operator SimplerThingThatLooksSimilar(ComplexNonSerializableClass other)
    {   // ... real code here, obviously
        return new SimplerThingThatLooksSimilar { Name = "abc", Whatever = 123 };
    }
    public static implicit operator ComplexNonSerializableClass(SimplerThingThatLooksSimilar other)
    {
        return new ComplexNonSerializableClass(); // ... real code here, obviously
    }

    [ProtoMember(1)]
    public string Name { get; set; }
    [ProtoMember(2)]
    public int Whatever { get; set; }
}

}
```. I'm glad you were able to make progress; I'm going to close this, but feel free to ping me if there's something else.. The library always intends to be as compatible in every direction as possible. That is a key aim of both protobuf as a general concept, and protobuf-net as a specific implementation of protobuf.
In the case of DateTimeKind - this data is tagged in as an additional optional field. As you correctly assume, if an older library doesn't know what to do with that, it will just ignore it.
Note that this is not always possible, though. As a specific example, Google added "Timestamp" as a common standard for storing date-time data (long after I'd written protobuf-net's DateTime representation). I plan to add Timestamp support in 2.3.0, probably doing something like:
[ProtoMember(1, DataFormat = DataFormat.WellKnown)]
public DateTime When {get;set;}

This uses a different format. If there was old code that used 2.1.0 (or whatever) and had (since DataFormat.WellKnown doesn't exist yet):
[ProtoMember(1)]
public DateTime When {get;set;}

then when this code tries to deserialize the time, it will either fail or silently come up with a nonsensical value. Ultimately, changing the DataFormat property of a member is almost always a breaking change in your data. I do not plan on changing the default DateTime / DataFormat matching, for exactly the reasons you highlight: compatibility.
The protobuf wire format has not changed at all, even with the addition of proto3 - so there shouldn't be any fundamentally changing ideas, at least until some hypothetical proto4; and if that happens, I would expect to add configuration options to enable this, so that nothing changes how existing code behaves. For example, if that happened, I would probably change:
public void Serialize<T>(Stream s, T value, ...

to:
[Obsolete("Please explicitly specify the protocol version; Proto2 is assumed by default")]
public void Serialize<T>(Stream s, T value, ...) => Serialize<T>(s, value, ProtocolVersion.Proto2);
public void Serialize<T>(Stream s, T value, ProtocolVersion version, ...)

if that makes sense. Basically, I will always go out of my way to avoid making it easy to fail. Which is, IMO, the entire point of a library.. I literally threw CommonCodeGenerator together as a starting point. I'm completely open to other radical ideas, although also note that CodeGenerator (the base) doesn't use that pattern at all - it may be that is the better fit for your scenario?. they're right next to the file in your own link (top post); https://github.com/mgravell/protobuf-net/blob/parser/src/protogen/CodeGenerator.cs. ? I'm open to the idea; I'm just not sure that there's a necessity for it... and global options are almost always problematic, especially in complex systems where one bit of code expects the global option to be one way, and another bit of code expects it to be the opposite.. K; interesting thing I notice: in proto3 (and in contrast to proto2), there is a new additional paragraph that clarifies how it expects unknown enums to be handled:

During deserialization, unrecognized enum values will be preserved in the message, though how this is represented when the message is deserialized is language-dependent. In languages that support open enum types with values outside the range of specified symbols, such as C++ and Go, the unknown enum value is simply stored as its underlying integer representation.

Because of this, I think it is entirely reasonable for proto3-based generation to automatically include EnumPassthru = true. It helps that proto3 has more sensible rules for enums that make this more ... possible.
I notice that RTB is implicitly a proto2 schema, so the interesting question for me is: "should we interpret this paragraph as applying retrospectively to proto2?". And if we do: what are the consequences? Are there problems where this will be actively harmful?
Let me have a think about that. It might be that we can magic this away completely, especially if we detect that the enum looks proto3 compatible (meaning: the first enum item has the value of zero).
It looks like the RTB enums would satisfy this rule.
Thoughts?. Ooh, I also need to thank you for the example; looks like the upcoming 2.3.0 parser needs a few more tweaks - it fails on that proto schema (see here) in two ways:

it doesn't expect hex numbers, giving "unable to parse integers" on everything in NativeAdTemplate.Fields
it fails to resolve Hyperlocal.Point correctly

I expect both of these to be easy fixes - will have a look this evening.. The annoying problem with enums in C# is that they don't have a defined order, and in proto2 the order matters (because the first one is the default). I think the rule for automatic "yeah, this is passthru" should be:

if [Flags] or [ProtoContract(EnumPassthru=true)] - trivial case, explicitly pass-thru

otherwise:

if there's an enum definition with value zero
and if there is no enum definition that has a [ProtoEnum(...)] marker with a value that is different than the enum's native value
and if there is not a [DefaultValue(...)] on the member that gives a value other than zero

then: treat it as pass-thru
I think that works......?. The more I think about it, the more I think we should only worry about this if there is a [ProtoEnum] with a non-matching value... i.e. do we actually need to do any mapping. If we don't: just pass it through as-is; which means at the DSL layer, both proto2 and proto3 can include this happily. It is only user-generated "code-first" enums that would ever have this problem.. What you say about VideoFormat is fine if we use the "The more I think about it" version, i.e. "as long as we don't know that there is a conflict: use the simple rules". This would only ever apply to "I'm using enums that I wrote in my regular non-.proto code, and I've added ProtoEnum to remap the values". This is a tiny edge case, and I'm OK if things are more complicated for that scenario. The default thing isn't a factor there - was just being paranoid - separate concern.
BTW, I fixed the parser - it almost works perfectly for that .proto now - only issue is the emitted code doesn't give quite the right name - it says public Point CenterPoint { get; set; } when it should be public Hyperlocal.Point CenterPoint { get; set; }. That's a known issue (it was already in the "Pending work items in generated code" list) that I'll try to fix tonight.. @rstonkus "exactly!" - the fact that is unclear highlights how unusual a situation that is. But basically, protobuf-net supports the hypothetical situation where you have an enum:
enum Foo {
    A = 0, B = 17, C = 42
}

And for whatever reason you want to use that in a model that is (perhaps at a later date) being exposed to protobuf but where the protobuf enum has values 0, 1, 4. In that scenario you can add [ProtoEnum(Value = 1)] against B and [ProtoEnum(Value = 4)] against C, and those values will be used in the serialization. This is a very unusual scenario, and is the only one where the pass-thru would appear to be unsafe. Having a [ProtoEnum] marker by itself is fine, as is using the same value in the ProtoEnum and the .NET enum.

If you're targetting .NET 3.5, then it is System.Xml 2.0; .NET 3.5 are incremental additions to .NET 2.0 via additional assemblies; the base assembles do not change (except for bugfixes etc, but they didn't increase the major version).
Because System.Xml.Linq is one of those additions in .NET 3.5, it gets the 3.5 versioning; however System.Xml: does not - it stays 2.0
In .NET 4.0, they all become 4.0.. AFAIK (and I'm happy to be corrected): System.Xml 3.5 does not exist.. at least, not in regular .NET. If it exists in some Mono / Unity / whatever branch, then fine.. Closing issue; 2.3.0 will include 2.0 and 3.5 builds via the "VS" configuration (that only works in VS, hence the name). spec) is designed such that data is appended, not replaced.
The good news is that there are two ways to fix this:
1) don't run the initializer during deserialization - you do this by adding
SkipConstructor = true to the [ProtoContract]
2) tell protobuf-net to not interpret the list data as append; add
OverwriteList = true to the [ProtoMember]
Either of these should achieve what you want

[ProtoContract]
class A
{
    public A() { Values = new int[5]; }
[ProtoMember(1)]
public int[] Values { get; set; }

{
     A a, b;

     a.Values[0] = 5;
 using (var ms = new MemoryStream())
 {
     Serializer.Serialize(ms, a);
     ms.Seek(0, SeekOrigin.Begin);
     b = Serializer.Deserialize<A>(ms);
 }
 Console.WriteLine("Sizes: {0}, {1}", a.Values.Length, b.Values.Length);

}
After deserialization b.Values contains 10 elements instead 5.

. K, this is a complex one.

Currently, the support for .net native and UWP / AOT etc is limited. As back-story, historically there is a precompilation tool for protobuf-net that allows limited cross-platform pre-compilation of the IL pieces. This kinda worked, but was awkward, ugly, really hard to support, and just generally messy. Additionally, this is going to be a nightmare as we add "async" (on the roadmap).
I don't think that is the way to go in the future, although the google code download still has the bits for this.
I have repeatedly been talking with MS and other folks re better ways of doing code-gen for this and other scenarios, for two different needs - the code-first approach and the contract-first approach. There are a range of plans to improve what is available here in the mid-range future. Basically the plan is to split the non-IL pieces (the reader/writer, etc) into "protobuf-net.Core" or similar. Projects would target the .Core project if they have generated C#, or both .Core and protobuf-net if they want to use the runtime emitter. The idea being that AOT scenarios would fall into the first camp.
At the moment, though, that mostly doesn't exist.
In the r668 world there is a core-only project that uses reflection. We could probably resurrect that short term, but the performance won't be anything to shout about.
So: are you looking for something today? Or is this "in the next n months" stuff?

. Looks good, thanks. It means it will either read zero bytes (already at the end of a stream,
you just didn't know), or it will consume an entire varint. Partial data is
not supported - if it reads an incomplete varint it will throw. TCP is a
stream, so if you use this method on a NetworkStream it will still work as
long as the data arrives eventually.

If you are processing a back-buffer in a MemoryStream, you may have to
manually check for a complete varint - or just catch the exception. To
check, you need to test at most 10 bytes to see if the MSB is zero. Once
you have a zero MSB, you're good to go.

. There are a few things that make this more awkward when starting from interfaces. Firstly, we can't just serialize it as a Class1 - it would need to be wrapped appropriately, which would mean any interface members at the root level, which would then probably end up being duplicated at the type level (because people would forget to exclude them), which is especially problematic for lists / arrays.

Secondly, it is very hard to deal with interfaces as the root object, since when using GetType() you lose the declared type and only have the concrete type. This would potentially make it serialize differently per context, which is very awkward. Likewise when the class type is used directly without mention of the interface.
This scenario is a lot more nuanced then is obvious. It would need very clear consideration as to how it would behave in a range of scenarios including (but not limited to) these cases.. > Can you explain why that is the case for an interface but not the case for a class that extends a base class?
It is the case for a base-class / sub-class. The difference is that a subclass doesn't usually re-declare (new etc) the same properties that the base class had. Most interface implementations, however: do.

Isn't this a good thing? You simply serialise it as a the concrete type which in my example is what I would like it to do.

it cannot simply be serialized as the concrete type - that will not work in any way. During deserialization it needs to know what type to deserialize. Serializing it as the type itself includes zero such metadata, so you'd be thinking IFoo and seeing data for Bar, but with no clue that it is a Bar. This is why it needs wrapping in the first place.

Well yes, because its an interface it would serialise as whatever the underlying object is. Wouldn't that be what most people expect?

See above.
The aim is fine, but it isn't as simple as just serializing as the concrete type. As I say: any approach here would need very clear ideas of what should happen (ideally in terms of the data protocol) in each case.. No. The problem is that the serialization of a Foo does not include anything that says "I'm a Foo".
If we did that, then during deserialization: how do you know what it should be?. A lot of the code does use exactly GetType() etc. That doesn't change he nature of the problem in any way. Types don't change their members, so it doesn't matter when we check if it will be the same shape either way.. Because this stuff is nuanced :)
There are 3 different scenarios here, and we'd need to know how each should behave:

root objects via generic usage such as Serialize<T> uses typeof(T) IIRC
root objects via non-generic usage may or may not have a type specified
members inside types know the member's type

Frankly, I don't think the problem that you're trying to solve is very clear at the moment. And the key point is: it isn't enough to serialize - we also need to be able to deserialize knowing just the interface.. Indeed, but we start getting into problems.
Consider: in order to serialize such a model, we need to find the logical root, which in this case probably is the interface - so: imagine we have:
[ProtoContract, ProtoInclude(10, typeof(Foo))]
interface IFoo {
   [ProtoMember(1)] int Id {get;set;}
}
[ProtoContract, ProtoInclude(10, typeof(Bar))]
class Foo : IFoo {
    public int Id {get;set;}
    // ...
}
[ProtoContract]
class Bar : Foo { ... }

So far so good. If we see a Bar, we need to build the model. Currently we just look at the .BaseType, which is simple and readily available - we find Foo, notice that there is an "include" and note that Bar's logical root is Foo, and we start from there.
So; let's say we want to fully support interfaces. Now we need to look not just at the .BaseType of each level, but also at the interfaces implemented by each level - and check them for "include" directives. In theory that's fine - we can find IFoo easily enough and determine that IFoo is the logical root for Foo and Bar.
Note that this is not the same as just serializing the concrete type - we need to start at the logical root in order to be able to deserialize correctly (we need to identify the correct type). This is one of the key points I was trying to call out earlier, although perhaps that is largely an implementation detail (it is a very important one). It would also be necessary to observe that adding an interface using this kind of "include" approach is fundamentally a breaking serialization change in the same way that adding a new base-type (with "include") is a breaking serialization change. But it can probably work - it just doesn't today.
It gets more complex, though - we'd need to think about what scenarios we don't support and how to message the user. For example:
[ProtoContract, ProtoInclude(10, typeof(SomeType))]
interface IFoo {...}
[ProtoContract, ProtoInclude(10, typeof(SomeType))]
interface IBar {...}

[ProtoContract]
class SomeType : IFoo, IBar { ... }

This doesn't have a sensible common root, and cannot be supported. Then we get into interfaces implementing interfaces (IFoo : IBar), etc. Should that work? 
This is probably fine, for example:
[ProtoContract, ProtoInclude(10, typeof(IBar))]
interface IFoo {...}
[ProtoContract, ProtoInclude(10, typeof(SomeType))]
interface IBar : IFoo {...}
[ProtoContract]
class SomeType : IBar { ...}

But what if we get to the same concrete type via multiple paths?

We also get into fun scenarios around unknown data and different versions of the contract; this is mostly the same scenario that we already have today for abstract classes, so it isn't drastically a new problem - but it is one that needs consideration

I guess the point I'm getting at here is that this is a complex problem. It isn't impossible to do it - but rather, it needs serious consideration and design and testing - plus of course whatever changes it needs to implement it, and document it, and update any now-wrong documents/questions on the topic, and fix any code regressions, and update any tests that now fail incorrectly because of the changes, and support these changes at every point in the future. We can't just shoe-horn it in with a 5 line hack. And before I take on significant pieces of work, I like to understand why we're doing it - i.e. what use case it supports that can't already be supported in other ways. Ultimately, time spent working on this is time not spent working on other code, so it is all a juggling act re how to spend resources (mostly: my time). It seems to me that everything here can already be achieved via a DTO layer. I'm not saying we can't do it, but I'd really want to explore what the compelling example is for doing it.. In the example you give, during deserialization, how would the code know to select SomeType? what members are serialized? are the members on IFoo serialized? or just those on SomeType? What happens if the list contains multiple different IFoo implementations? Why is SomeType tested for, specifically? What happens if there aren't any known IFoo implementations? What happens if I serialize a SomeType instance by itself? Does that look the same as an IFoo that was a SomeType? Does a List<SomeType> look identical to a List<IFoo>?
These are the questions that I'd need to get to the bottom of.. > When you start deserialising you know what you are deserialising due to the ProtoMember numbers in the data don't you? So from these you can infer the type that was serialised eg in this case SomeClass?
How? where did that number come from? If we take your specfic example: where would it get such a number from? The only possible place is a [ProtoInclude] on the interface,  which takes us back to the more complex scenario that I strongly suspect is the only way to do it.

When you start the deserialization process and you receive the memberNumber do you not look up the class of this member number? I'm not sure how this problem is unique to interfaces.

The member number only tells us that we're talking about the ListOfIFoo member.. If you mean "treat all IFoo as though they were SomeType, and fail if one isn't, and just use SomeType during deserialization"... then frankly I think it should be a List<SomeType>.... > It would get the number from SomeClass, it would never look at anything about the interface implementation.
That just tells us to expect IFoo. We don't know about SomeType from that

Upon deserialisation you check every single object Is An IFoo and cast it to IFoo

I think the key thing you're missing here is context on how deserialization works and what data the protobuf stream contains. The ultimate problem is: the data in the raw stream doesn't tell us what type of object to create. A List<Blah> when deserialized doesn't create Blah instances "because the data tells us to". Rather, it creates Blah instances because it is deserializing a List<Blah>. As such, it interprets the data (which is otherwise unadorned) using the rules for Blah. So: you can't just deserialize and then cast to IFoo - we need to know what to actually do with the data that we see. This is what the "logical root / include" approach of protobuf-net does - it defines a set of conventions for interpreting an inheritance based model.. K; the way protobuf-net encodes that is essentially (to use .proto syntax):
message DTO {
    repeated BaseClass listOfBase  = 5;
}
message BaseClass {
    optional ExtendsBase1 _eb1 = 1;
    optional ExtendsBase2 _eb2 = 2;
}
message ExtendsBase1 {
    optional string Test3 = 3;
}
message ExtendsBase2 {
    optional string Test4 = 4;
}

where exactly zero or one of _eb1 / _eb2 are assigned a value (this could also use oneof in recent .proto versions). The sub-classes are mapped as inner objects, and the sub-class data always comes first. In JSON terms (although it isn't JSON - this is purely for example purposes), an object would look something like:
{
   "_eb1": {
    "Test3": "foo"
  }
}

During deserialization, we start with a null reference, and start resolving fields, and only create the instance when required (because of data fields, or at the end of any deserialization path). Since the first actual data we get is the "Test3", it is at that point that we create the instance, which we know by the context should be a ExtendsBase1. If neither _eb1 or eb2 had a value, then we'd create a BaseClass instance on the way out (or when some data in that context was encountered, but there aren't any other fields in this case).

My point in the comment yesterday is that we could apply this same logic to interfaces, within certain constraints - mainly around the topics of multiple inheritance (resolving to contract types) would be disallowed.
So essentially, it could be mapped with the interface as the root type:
message IFoo {
    optional SomeType _st = 1;
    optional SomeOtherType _sot = 2;
}

which would map to:
[ProtoContract]
[ProtoInclude(1, typeof(SomeType))]
[ProtoInclude(2, typeof(SomeOtherType))]
interface IFoo {...}

This would allow us to deserialize an IFoo into any of the known / expected concrete types. This obviously has the issue that if no expected type is found in the data, then it can't instantiate - but that's actually the same problem we get for abstract base classes today, so that's not a new restriction.. This is #276 and is fixed and available on nuget: https://mgravell.github.io/protobuf-net/releasenotes. I can do a "non pre-release" build if it would help; I was waiting on
dogfooding results, but we've been using 2.3.0-gamma on Stack Overflow
successfully, so we're probably OK for that smoke test.

. In the C#, I assume that is a System.DateTime, not your own DateTime message? In which case indeed: the way that protobuf-net will encode that System.DateTime is not the same as your DateTime message in the .proto

Good news: fixable.
Options:

if you need to keep the DateTime from your .proto, you can do that but you'll need to create a .NET type that looks like that - presumably simply by running your .proto through protogen (https://protogen.marcgravell.com is the easiest way to do this)
alternatively, use google.protobuf.Timestamp, the "well known" mechanism to express date/time info - protobuf-net supports this, including protogen (you'll need to import "google/timestamp.proto") and code-first (use DataFormat.WellKnown on that property); note that this option replaces the DateTime you've defined in your .proto and will change the data - and the change needs to be shared between all callers

Other options exist, but those are the simplest. Note: if you have existing protobuf-net data that was serialized with the class shown, and you want to deserialize that in another client - then: it gets harder. Until relatively recently there was no "well known" format for dates/times, so protobuf-net invented one. Unfortunately the representation it used is not the one that got chosen, and is awkward to use from other clients. There is a .proto for it, though - see bcl.proto / DateTime: https://github.com/mgravell/protobuf-net/blob/master/src/Tools/bcl.proto
If possible, when using cross-platform clients, I suggest moving to the new "well known" formats for dates/times, but: this is fundamentally incompatible with any existing data stored using the bcl.proto approach.. thats very odd; I will need to take a look, but that "actual" indeed looks
very unlikely

. If you are just using the library (the dll, etc), then there is no
dependency whatsoever on any google code.

Partly, the wording is included as a courtesy and to make it very obvious
that the underlying protocol ("protobuf") that protobuf-net implements is a
google property.
However, additionally: among the additional tools available in the
protobuf-net packages are copies of "protoc" and multiple google .proto
files. Historically, "protoc" was used by the "protogen" tool, although
this is no longer the case (the "protogen" tool is now entirely managed
code with no dependency); however, the source code also includes the code
for https://protogen.marcgravell.com/ which again includes "protoc" as a
convenience for people working with multiple languages, and multiple .proto
files (mostly by google) to allow people to make use of common "import"
scenarios.
Does that help?

. That is simply not a good idea, but you could probably get around it via:
[ProtoMember(4)]
public SomeType TheOriginalProperty {get;set;}
then migrating to:
```
[ProtoMember(4)]
public SomeType TheOriginalProperty {...}
public bool ShouldSerializeTheOriginalProperty()
{
    return false;
}
[ProtoMember(12)]
public int TheNewProperty {...}
```
with one of the two properties being the "actual" code, and one of them
being a shim that has the code to translate between the two. This approach
will allow both old and new data to be read, but data will always be
written using the new layout.

. The test project didn't contain comparisons to protobuf-csharp-port, so it
is hard for me to comment, but my initial thought is: the google
implementation does a lot of the serialization work in the builder, so if
you aren't measuring object construction time and object query time - that
is probably a huge part of the difference. The MS impl is a more
feature-parity comparison. I've tidied up some glitches in the code (let me
know if you want the revised .cs back), and I get data like:

Test1 (MS.LiveLabs) ser:1594 deser:1531 len:442
Test2 (protobuf-net) ser:1172 deser:2156 len:432
Test1 (MS.LiveLabs) ser:1625 deser:2047 len:442
Test2 (protobuf-net) ser:1437 deser:3391 len:432
Test1 (MS.LiveLabs) ser:1594 deser:1531 len:442
Test2 (protobuf-net) ser:1156 deser:2250 len:432
Test1 (MS.LiveLabs) ser:1610 deser:1531 len:442
Test2 (protobuf-net) ser:1156 deser:2250 len:432
Test1 (MS.LiveLabs) ser:1609 deser:1532 len:442
Test2 (protobuf-net) ser:1156 deser:2172 len:432
General conclusions, then: at the moment, protobuf-net on the data is
faster at serialization, but slightly slower on deserialization.
Investigating the exact time is tricky, and I can't give an immediate
answer on that, but it is something I can look at to see if there's a
"trick" I can do here. But overall, they are very comparable. I'm not sure
it is worth getting excited over the difference between them....

. k; thanks for the update
. This is actually the correct application of reading an individual value; in
the protobuf wire format, streams can be directly appended. If a field is
duplicated, it is the last occurrence that wins (except for sub-items,
where they are merged). To do anything different would be to parse the data
incorrectly. To read lists, you should use the separate "items" based
method - apologies, I am on mobile and don't have the name to hand.

On 8 Oct 2014 11:05, "tbella" notifications@github.com wrote:

The BufferPool throws OutOfMemory exception when serializing large objects
on x86 platforms. In our case one of the fields is a byta array containing
64 MB data. Possible improvements:
- Remove buffering from ProtoWriter: dirently write to the stream,
  buffering should be performed by the underlying stream.
- Do not only cache default-sized buffers. The real gain would be in
  caching big buffers allocated on the Large Object Heap. They are
  responsible for memory fragmentation and also more expensive to re-allocate.
- Use weak references for cached buffers. They could be automatically
  collected in low-memory situations.
- Re-use cached buffers in ResizeAndFlushLeft method.

. So to be clear, then; what makes you think there is a problem? The 9 bytes in the binary you posted most recently says:
"field 11, string, length 7" (2 bytes)
    "field 3, string, length 5" (2 bytes)
        "SOLNA" (5 bytes)
If field 11 is a location with Coordinate = null, Accuracy = 0 and City = "SOLNA", then that is entirely reasonable. So: what makes you think there is an issue? What is the symptom? 
. From your comment here:

The first thing it reads, inside this nested message, is buffer position 202: 7. It uses the two lines above making tag=7 and therefore fieldNumber=0.

what you are describing here is a bug in protostuff; a tag with value 90 indicates a length-prefixed type (aka "string"). The correct thing to do next is to read a varint, which indicates the length of the content - in this case, 7 bytes. The content starts after the 7. If protostuff isn't reading the varint that denotes the length: then it is doing it wrong. You can refer to the "Strings" and "Embedded Messages" sections of the encoding spec for more information.

. Ah, this is probably the annoying "implicit defaults" - an early design choice that is much regretted. Try adding:
[DefaultValue(true)]
To the property. That should hopefully fit it.
. This is simply a poor design choice that happened many many years ago in v1 of protobuf-net. What I should have done is only use explicit default values. How the code was implemented - and remains the default, for compatibility - is that it assumes "zero" as the default, unless told otherwise (or unless some kind of conditional serialization is in play, for example Nullable-of-T, ShouldSerialize, or Specified). There is actually an option to disable this if you create your own RuntimeTypeModel instance rather than using .Default - something like ".UseImplicitZeroDefaults".
The [DefaultValue(true)] in this case simply gives the library more clue as to what is an actual value vs a default.
. the fundsmental thing here is that the .proto schema proessing needs a
singnificant overhaul (read: rewrite) in order to be viable in the
xplat/core-clr world. This would be a natural thing to fold into that, but
in some ways I'm reluctant to stir too hard at the old protoc/xslt code.
the good-ish news is that it is all protocol compatible, but I acknowledge
that it is inconvenient to do so. Needs work, and I have a chunk of time
earmarked for protobuf-net love this quarter.

probably need to do is:

  the extra parameter (and in the case of EmitWrite: to select the correct
  method, which could perhaps be done by making EmitWrite ignore methods
  where [Obsolete] is defined)

The point of this lot is due to the ability of protobuf-net to generate
serialization assemblies; we don't want old serialization assemblies to
break with MissingMethodException, and we want newly generated
serialization assemblies to respect the options that were set on their
RuntimeTypeModel.
That lot probably isn't trivial, though - and depends on reflection/IL
knowledge. I might be able to jump in and help on some of that if it is
problematic. I'm open to alternative implementation ideas too!

. Actually, there is something you can do here if and only if the additional data is a direct child of the original root object. For example: if the original is:

Foo {
    a = 1;
    b = 2;
    repeated c = 3;
}
The protobuf format is both:
- appendable (append===merge)
- not required to be in order
This means that you can actually drop the "b" part (for example) onto the wire separately from the rest, simply by appending it correctly. To append with the right headers, the easiest thing to do is to create a dummy object with just the b:
FooBOnly {
    b = 2;
}
Now you can:
- serialize a Foo that doesn't include a "b"
- serialize a FooBOnly with a "b"
When the receiver seaerializes as Foo, it will merge both parts automatically.
Any use?

. I don't think it is a good idea to leak the actual ioBuffer, because that is leased from the BufferPool -  basically:
- the contents might have been changed completely by another caller by the time the recpient sees it
- it would allow the recipient to screw up someone else's ioBuffer

I'd be fine with adding context about the position, length, etc... but the ioBuffer: probably not a good idea
. I would also question the usefulness; it isn't like xml and json - most people won't have a clue how to interpret the data.
. the only way to safely do that would be to grab the data from the ioBuffer before adding it to the exception, so the only thing you're adding is isolated; however, protobuf is a binary format, and in the general case we should not expect it to be likely to contain text
. ioBuffer can be pretty huge, though - I would advise only copying (say) a max of 100 bytes either side of where it exploded (would need some min/max checks, etc); additionally, note that you should only look at most at the known available bytes - anything past that point is potentially garbage and unrelated to the current problem: it would be unnecessarily confusing to report that as though it were part of the problem, when it isn't.
Finally, in terms of allocation and large blocks, this isn't ideal - it kinda feels like this should be opt-in (although it is fine if the message says "enable ShowBufferContentsInExceptions to view the data at the time of the error", or something like that)

. Protocol buffers at the protocol level doesn't define inheritance at
all. Protobuf-net adds limited inheritance support, but things like
multiple inheritance is complex; to do that properly would require
considerable design, implementation and testing, for what is an edge
scenario - and arguably one better served by mapping to a simpler DTO model
that (as is the nature of DTOs) reflects the reality of the serialisation
paradigm.

This isn't on my planned list of things to do. If someone can absorb the
time to properly specify, proove (i.e. that it is unambiguous, etc),
design, implement, test, document and support it - I would consider a PR
for it.

. 1: yes
2: in terms of the protobuf specification, each sub-type is implemented as
an optional sub-message using that numeric identifier
3: this is not uncommon in serialisation; compare/contrast [XmlInclude];
the problem is that during deserialization the only thing you usually know
is the parent, hence it becomes necessary for the parent to know about the
derived types

static public void SerializeAsProtobuf(string filePath, object obj)
{
    using (FileStream fileStream = new FileStream(filePath, FileMode.OpenOrCreate))
    {
        SerializeAsProtobuf(fileStream, obj);
        fileStream.Close();
    }
}
static public void SerializeAsProtobuf(Stream stream, object obj)
{
    Serializer.Serialize(stream, obj);
}
static public ExtendedItem1 DeserializeProtobuf(string filePath)
{
    using (FileStream fileStream = new FileStream(filePath, FileMode.Open, FileAccess.Read, FileShare.ReadWrite))
    {
        ExtendedItem1 product = DeserializeProtobuf(fileStream);
        fileStream.Close();
        return product;
    }
}
static public ExtendedItem1 DeserializeProtobuf(Stream stream)
{
    return ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize(stream);
}
```

typeMeta.AddField(1, nameof(Foo.Bar)).DefaultValue = 0;

. Protobuf-net needs to know numbers for each field you want to serialize. There are ways to make this semi-automated, but the easiest way would be to explicitly mark them:
```
[DataMember(Order=1)]
public string ABC {get;set;}
[DataMember(Order=2)]
public int QWE {get;set;}
```
That should fix it.
. Well, in this scenario the first thing I'd note is that using implementation details (such as Microsoft.Crm.Sdk.Entity) in serialization layers is not a great idea - it creates a huge number of traps. Frankly, if serialization of an existing object model becomes non-trivial, the best approach is not "fight the serializer" but rather "create a simple DTO that fits the serializer perfectly"
As it happens, protobuf-net does have things like ImplicitFields that can help in some of these scenarios, but it only looks at the declaring type, not base-types - so it wouldn't pull from Entity. protobuf-net also has the ability to configure types manually, but that would require you adding code to your app-init. But to give an example broadly similar to yours:
```
using ProtoBuf;
using ProtoBuf.Meta;
using System;
using System.Runtime.Serialization;
class Program {
    static void Main() {
        RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(MyObj), false).Add("Foo", "Bar", "Name");
        var obj = new MyObj { Name = "abc", Foo = 123, Bar = "def" };
        var clone = Serializer.DeepClone(obj);
        Console.WriteLine(obj);
        Console.WriteLine(clone);
    }
}
[DataContract] public class MyObj : Entity {
    [DataMember] public string Name { get; set; }
    public override string ToString() => $"{Name}, {Foo}, {Bar}";
}
[DataContract] public class Entity {
    [DataMember] public int Foo { get; set; }
    [DataMember] public string Bar { get; set; }
}
```
Note here that the order of the members in Add defines their wire identity - so Foo is 1, Bar is 2, etc. Depending on your C# version, you may also wish to look at nameof rather than hard-coded strings:
RuntimeTypeModel.Default.Add(typeof(MyObj), false).Add(
            nameof(Entity.Foo), nameof(Entity.Bar), nameof(MyObj.Name));
Is any of that useful?
. Microsoft.Xrm.Sdk.AttributeCollection is basically a
Dictionary, which protobuf-net is going to hate. The
protobuf format is designed to serialize models with a well-known shape /
format - which "object" isn't. There is no good way to handle a
string-object map in protobuf; there are some bad ways, but that depends a
lot on what the actual values are in your scenario.
. The problem isn't the map - protobuf-net would happily support
Dictionary<string,Project>, to use the example from your links; it is the
"object". Protobuf wants to know what it is deserializing. So again: what
are the actual values?

model specifically intended for serialization, that represents the data

. oddly, no not really. You see, there aren't any binary serialization format
changes between proto2 and proto3, so you can already do everything. The
DSL changes just make it more elegant in some cases if you're using .proto
schemas. Which has never been a hard requirement in protobuf-net. The
runtime in proto3 for protobuf-net aren't huge - the biggest things are the
addition of Duration / Timestamp support and cleaner Map handling, but:
they're done. I haven't started the attribs=>proto3 work; proto3 is
actually a subset of proto2, not a superset as you might imagine. The
challenge for me will be to see what I can live without :)

K; I've fixed the library to stop it exploding, but the fundamental problem here is that a type (to protobuf-net) can either be a leaf or a list, not both; in being enumerable of itself, it tries to be both. The code isn't going to like the "list" style (it ... just doesn't parse), so it now reverts to "leaf". This will, however, mean that to get this to behave as you expect, you will need to still expose the downstream tree; this could be done by:

[ProtoMember(3)] // or whatever
protected List<TreeObject> _children =
. Note: to fix this using the existing library, you should be able to do:
[ProtoContract(IgnoreListHandling = true)]
class Problematic : IEnumerable
{
    [ProtoMember(3)] // or whatever
    protected List<TreeObject> _children =
here the IgnoreListHandling is checked before the code that is currently causing it to explode.
. The problem here is that it grarually becomes prohibitively and
disproportionately time consuming to support older runtimes. For context,
MS .NET 4.51 support ended over a year ago (
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2014/08/07/moving-to-the-net-framework-4-5-2/
).
This is especially challenging given the changes to the build process etc.
Which needs another overhaul for the csproj changes, but that's another
story.
The long and short, then, will be:

if I do the csproj changes (imminent) and the old versions "just work"
(meaning: fall into place without me going crazy), then great: I'll include
them
otherwise, if someone can figure out what the csproj and build changes
are to make it successfully target those versions without causing problems,
then a PR will be gratefully received and merged

Historically I have tried to consider back-level - heck, it even used to
compile on C#1.2 (.Net 1.1), and might still do so! But: there comes a time
when it isn't the best use of my time to try to do so.
I also have concerns that continuing to support these very very old
runtimes is me being an "enabler" when what I should actually be doing is
advocating for you to move to an up to date framework.

binary format, however, is unchanged - so as long as you understand how
proto3 translates to the object model, it is readily consumable. I'm open
to offers from anyone who wants to update the schema parsing tooling - they
are long overdue some love. But the primary API in protobuf-net has
always been code-first, which simply isn't impacted at all by proto3.

On 25 November 2016 at 09:26, Anton van Dijk notifications@github.com
wrote:

An issue could be that the stream is being read at the wrong position.
Besides that, it might not be done writing when you're calling the
deserialize.
Instead of:
var serverStream = new MemoryStream();
ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(serverStream, responseMsg);
Console.WriteLine($"responseMsg {responseMsg?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");
var response =ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize(serverStream);
Console.WriteLine($"response {response?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");
Try:
var serverStream = new MemoryStream();
ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(serverStream, responseMsg);
Console.WriteLine($"responseMsg {responseMsg?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");
serverStream.Flush();
serverStream.Position = 0;
var response =ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize(serverStream);
Console.WriteLine($"response {response?.responseStr ?? "failed"}\n");

automatically generate classes to represent a 2.0 schema.

I wrote a test that can exercise this issue:
    [TestMethod, TestCategory("RecruitmentEdge"), Owner("RecruitmentEdge@careerbuilder.com")]
    public void Verify_Protobuf_Serialization()
    {
        using (var writeStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream())
        {
            ISet<String> mySet = new HashSet<String>();
            mySet.Add("hello world");

            ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(writeStream, mySet);

            using (var readStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream(writeStream.ToArray()))
            {
                var myDeserializedSet = ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize<ISet<String>>(readStream);
                Assert.AreEqual(mySet.First(), myDeserializedSet.First());
                Assert.AreEqual("hello world", mySet.First());
            }
        }

        using (var writeStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream())
        {
            IDictionary<DayOfWeek, ISet<String>> myMap = new Dictionary<DayOfWeek, ISet<String>>();
            myMap.Add(DayOfWeek.Monday, new HashSet<string> { "hello world" });

            ProtoBuf.Serializer.Serialize(writeStream, myMap);

            using (var readStream = new System.IO.MemoryStream(writeStream.ToArray()))
            {
                var myDeserializedMap = ProtoBuf.Serializer.Deserialize<IDictionary<DayOfWeek, ISet<String>>>(readStream);
                Assert.AreEqual(myMap[DayOfWeek.Monday].First(), myDeserializedMap[DayOfWeek.Monday].First());
                Assert.AreEqual("hello world", myMap[DayOfWeek.Monday].First());
            }
        }
    }

Also, is it possible that you have the same repeated object in the tree
multiple times? (for example, a City object where 20 customers all have the
same City instance) - protobuf-net is a tree serializer by default, so that
data would be repeated. BF is a graph serializer that uses object tracking
- however protobuf-net also has this as an optional feature.
